BOSTON, Ray Charles. blind
blues singer and composer. wa s
ARE sted by federal authorities
La st Thursday for smuggling mar
cotics into the country from an
other one.


Charles plane wa s searched by
custom officials and a hypoder-
mic needle, a syringe, some
marijuana and heroin were found.


The singer has been arrested
many times in various cities for
possessing narcotics. He is an
admitted addict. but he ha never
served term.


If found guilty, the singer faces
a term in federal penitentiary. He
could be sentenced to maximum
of 40 years and $4,000 in fines.

Negroes voted overwhelmingly
for President Lyndon B. Johnson
helping to his landslide victory.
Of the estimated 5000. 900 reg
istered Negro voters, in some
areas 80 per cent voted.


Nationally, President Johnson
received 81 per cent of the total
vote ca st, in predominantly Negro
wards across the country. He
received from SO to SO per cent
of the vote, an increa Sc Of from
l8 to 80 points over the vote
ca st in the wards for John F.
Kennedy in 1860.


Four Harlem districts re-
turned total of 324 1924 for John
son and 57,59l Goldwater. Ra-
leigh, NC, Negroes in six pre-
cincts voted 5,ll8 Johnson. l3o

Alpha Chi Pi Omega Sorority
will sponsor the Ebony Fa shion
Fair, entitled, "Spanish Flair"
Dec. 2 at Phoenix Union High
School auditorium, 8 pm.


No local talent will be presen-

rent show which is headlined by

cal beauticians.

year or Jet = E months.

The Messengers, folk singers
from Los Angeles, will appear in
concert Sat-, Nov. FL, 8 pm.
at the Unitarian Church, 4027
E. Lincoln Drive.


Songs ofthe freedom movement
will be pre- sented. The group is
assisting In raising funds to help
student civil rights workers in
Mississippi.

Mississippi project include Rev.
l.. ]. Smallreed of the Scottsdale
Congregational United Church of

Goldwater.

heavily Negro districts gave
1888 63l in favor of the Presi-
dent. The predominatly Negro
Ward 9 in Columbia, Sc, ca st
2,203 votes Johnson. and SIS =
Goldwater.


Boston Negro voters piled upa
27.458 to 1874 ma ority for John
son in As precincts. Four pre-
dominantly Negro wards in Tam
pa, Fla, went 5,053 to 247 for
the Pre- sident. In Jacksonville,
Fla. the vote was 1904 Johnson,
IT Coldwater in four precincts.
In New Orleans. La, the vote
was 1906 for Johnson and e66
for Goldwater in SO precincts.

Christ and Greg Kaslo, Of APO
N. 55th Ave.


During the pa st summer nearly
1000 white and Negro students
were in Mississippi for planned
voters registration and other
educational programs.


Tickets costing 81 may be OBJ
tanned at the door or re servations
may be called to o47-7229.

social concerns of the Unitarian
Church of Phoenix.

Phoenix Urban League Guild
sponsors its annual membership
tea, Sum-, Nov. Is, at the Com
munity Services Bldg, ISIS E.
Osborn Rd., 3-5 pm.


Junius Bowman, newly appoin-
ted executive director, will be the
honored guest.


Cy Edwards, neighborhood
planning and coordinating consul
tant will be introduced, also.

FORT HUACHUCA : Lieuten-
ant Colonel Felix L. Goodwin has
assumed duties as Information
Officer here. Formerly the Post
services officer, Colonel Good
win succeeds Major Joseph E.
Wallace.


Col. Goodwin stressed the i'm
portance of command cooperation
in the ares of public information,
public relations, and command
information. "He said, "An in
formation officer job is diff
ficult without the support of every
member of the command"


Colonel Goodwin is neither a
stranger to Fort Huachuca nor
the public information business.
He was the information officer
of Joint Task Forces, the MI
clear Test Force in the Pacific
in 1862. Prior to his arrival
here he served S chief of the
One Army Liaison Branch, U.
S. Army Troop Information Sup
port Unit in Wa shington, DC.


His first association with Fort
Huachuca came in 1889 when he
began his army career here with
the 18th infantry Regiment. His
present Fort Hua chuca tour began
in August 1868.


The veteran of Is years Army
service is currently working on
his ma sters degree in Public Adj
ministration at the University of
Arizona. He was the first per-
son to be graduated on Okinawa
from the University of Maryland
overseas program.


Service School training during
the colonel s career includes the
Transportation School, Fort
Eustis. Va Q948), the Army Lam
guage School. Monterey, Calf.
(l955), where he studied Rus
sian, the Army Information
School, Fort Slocum. MY. (l96O)
and the advanced Public Relations
course at the University of Wis
consin (l96l).


Colonel Goodwin, his wife
Esther and their three daughters
now live in Tucson.

NO PLACE TO GO


Mayor Milton G2uhana's charges that cey-
tain dance halls sOeYe contributing to juvenile
delinquency carries more alarming mems than
many persons care to admit. Unfortunately
not all of the dance halls fYeQuented by the
younger set are aOel lighted or do ba1tenders
refuse to serve minors. There are many
places in the city where the managers honestly
try to keep order and obey all o1Os to b210tec ct
juvenile patrons.


One outstanding problem facing the city IS
caused by the lack of re cYg0tiOn0l facilities
for the thousands Of elementary, high school
and college students 1Vbo hve uitkin the Great
eY Phoenix enviyon Also, out OF Sc"oo' 'ee"-
ayers haze the same problems.


There are fen places north of the cks
and less south of the tracks. The tracks, of
course, symbolic the areas where the 'inaeY
city" appears. Beyond that boundary less than
a dozen city recreation centeys or Fairgrounds
are fostpd


There are practically no city operated or
sponsored re cYeatio,aal programs where the
majority of the Negro or INSTRUMENTATION
residents hve. Young boys and girls haze fen
places to go for some fun or relaxation.


Bows are more blessed be cause there are
tho United Fund supported Boys Clubs south
of the tracks Girls haze no place set aside
for them.


Before everyone lays all Of the blame on the
dance hail oa0neYs and managers, let us re-
member that adults must provide suitable rec
Yeation programs and centeYs for our eveY-
growing tee,aage population.


Parents must also yeatSym their roles Of
kgowing and caring where their children go.
Parents should organize and petition the city
council to provide more places of wholesome
recreation for our youth.


Churches could serve as community CenteTS
for small group activities during the week and
ON weekends for teenageTs.


All of us should heed the constant teen0ge
conablain that there is no place to go.
